definition.formal: Stroke in evolution refers to a syndrome of progressively worsening neurological deficits following the initial presentation of an acute ischemic stroke. Deterioration may be stepwise or gradual and reflects ongoing ischemia in the penumbral zone or extension of the infarct.
definition.clinical: A patient whose stroke symptoms are getting worse over hours to days, indicating that the brain injury is expanding and intervention may still salvage tissue.

core_concepts.explanation: Multiple mechanisms contribute: (1) ongoing embolization from proximal source, (2) propagation of thrombus in cerebral arteries, (3) failure of collateral circulation, (4) penumbral failure from hypoperfusion, (5) hemorrhagic transformation. The ischemic penumbra (at-risk but not yet infarcted tissue) is the therapeutic target.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Understanding the mechanism guides treatment. Thrombus propagation may respond to anticoagulation; embolic source requires intervention on that source.

core_concepts.explanation: Defined by documented neurological worsening on serial examinations. May be stepwise (sudden worsenings) or gradual (progressive decline). NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) increase of ≥2 points is commonly used threshold.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Requires frequent, documented neurological assessments. Early recognition triggers investigation and potential intervention.

core_concepts.explanation: Progression is most common in the first 24-48 hours after stroke onset. Late progression (>72 hours) is often due to complications (edema, hemorrhage, infection) rather than ongoing ischemia.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Early progression may be reversible with appropriate intervention. Late progression has different causes and management.

core_concepts.explanation: Repeat brain imaging (CT or MRI) is essential. DWI-MRI shows completed infarct. Perfusion imaging identifies penumbra (mismatch between perfusion deficit and infarct core). CTA or MRA identifies residual occlusion.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Imaging distinguishes treatable conditions (residual occlusion with penumbra) from untreatable (completed large infarct).

core_concepts.explanation: Ipsilateral severe carotid stenosis or occlusion may contribute to progression through reduced perfusion or ongoing embolization. Urgent revascularization may be considered in selected cases.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Vascular surgeon involvement is appropriate when stroke in evolution is associated with significant carotid disease.

signs_and_symptoms: Initial neurological deficit with documented worsening
Motor deficits may progress (arm → leg or vice versa)
New symptoms may emerge (e.g., visual field defect)
physical_examination: Assess for signs of elevated ICP (late finding)

differential_diagnosis.distinguishing_features: Sudden severe worsening, headache, decreased consciousness; CT shows hemorrhage
Occurs 2-5 days post-stroke, signs of mass effect on imaging
New symptoms not explained by initial lesion

general_measures: Head of bed at 30 degrees (if no contraindication)

anticoagulation.evidence: Limited evidence; used in selected cases with ongoing embolization

revascularization_options.indication: Large vessel occlusion with salvageable penumbra, extended window (up to 24h in selected)
revascularization_options.notes: Standard of care for appropriate candidates

revascularization_options.indication: Severe ipsilateral stenosis with ongoing TIAs or minor stroke
revascularization_options.notes: Controversial in completed stroke; avoid in large infarct

outcomes.outcomes: Patients with progression have higher disability and mortality compared to stable strokes.

learning_objectives: Define stroke in evolution and distinguish from stable stroke
Explain pathophysiological mechanisms causing stroke progression
Describe the role of serial neurological examinations
Outline treatment options for stroke in evolution
Identify when carotid intervention may be appropriate
key_takeaways: Stroke in evolution = worsening deficits indicating ongoing ischemia
Early progression may be reversible; late progression often from complications
Permissive hypertension - do not aggressively lower BP
Mechanical thrombectomy may be life-saving for large vessel occlusions
